articles.headline: For Savers, It Was Hardly a Lost Decade
articles.snippet: With diversification and regular contributions, many investors could have doubled their account balances in the last decade.
articles.abstract: With diversification and regular contributions, many investors could have doubled their account balances in the last decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the age of zeroes, the epoch of naughts, an era when we started with something and added just about nothing.

articles.headline: For Some in Japan, Home Is a Tiny Plastic Bunk
articles.snippet: Capsule hotels, built for salarymen who missed the train home, are becoming a last resort for the unemployed.
articles.abstract: Capsule hotels, built for salarymen who missed the train home, are becoming a last resort for the unemployed.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  For Atsushi Nakanishi, jobless since Christmas, home is a cubicle barely bigger than a coffin  one of dozens of berths stacked two units high in one of central Tokyo’s decrepit “capsule” hotels.

articles.headline: Time Warner and Fox Reach a Cable Deal
articles.snippet: The News Corporation and Time Warner Cable said that they had agreed on new terms for a contract, averting a blackout of college bowl games.
articles.abstract: The News Corporation and Time Warner Cable said that they had agreed on new terms for a contract, averting a blackout of college bowl games.
articles.lead_paragraph: The News Corporation and Time Warner Cable struck a deal just in time for the Sugar Bowl.

articles.headline: U.S. Loan Effort Is Seen as Adding to Housing Woes
articles.snippet: Some economists contend that the Obama administration’s $75 billion program to prevent foreclosures has done more harm than good.
articles.abstract: Some economists contend that the Obama administration’s $75 billion program to prevent foreclosures has done more harm than good.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration’s $75 billion program to protect homeowners from foreclosure has been widely pronounced a disappointment, and some economists and real estate experts now contend it has done more harm than good.

articles.headline: Paris, Milan, Tokyo. Tokyo?
articles.snippet: Tokyo’s clothing designers are cutting-edge and are frequently imitated, but their markets have remained mostly domestic.
articles.abstract: Tokyo’s clothing designers are cutting-edge and are frequently imitated, but their markets have remained mostly domestic.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Japan’s trailblazers of street fashion are the envy of Western designers, spawning Web sites filled with snapshots of Tokyo youngsters in the latest distressed jeans or psychedelic stockings.

articles.headline: Fragile Calm Holds in Darfur After Years of Death
articles.snippet: The western region of Sudan that has become virtually synonymous with conflict is “frozen” — stuck somewhere between war and peace.
articles.abstract: The western region of Sudan that has become virtually synonymous with conflict is “frozen” — stuck somewhere between war and peace.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL FASHER, Sudan  The changes across the landscape here would have been hard to imagine just a few years ago.

articles.headline: For Stocks in the Developed World, It Was a Decade of Zeros
articles.snippet: The developed world over all had a total return of only about 2 percent for the years from 2000 through 2009, and the United States did worse.
articles.abstract: The developed world over all had a total return of only about 2 percent for the years from 2000 through 2009, and the United States did worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a decade that began with such promise. Stock markets in Europe and America ended the 1990s at record levels, and even bedraggled Japan was at a two-year high. “Dow 36,000” was on some best-seller lists.

articles.headline: Better Vision for the World, on a Budget
articles.snippet: Efforts are under way to develop and distribute inexpensive adjustable eyeglasses to the world’s poor to help them lead more productive lives.
articles.abstract: Efforts are under way to develop and distribute inexpensive adjustable eyeglasses to the world’s poor to help them lead more productive lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: VEGHEL, the Netherlands  With AIDS, malaria and other diseases costing millions of lives every year, worrying about the vision of people in the developing world may seem like an indulgence.

articles.headline: Real Estate in Cape Coral Is Far From a Recovery
articles.snippet: The Florida city, a reluctant symbol for the excesses of the real estate bubble, shows how far the recovery has to go.
articles.abstract: The Florida city, a reluctant symbol for the excesses of the real estate bubble, shows how far the recovery has to go.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAPE CORAL, Fla.

articles.headline: Citi’s Creator, Alone With His Regrets
articles.snippet: Sandy Weill, the former head of Citigroup, says the bank didn’t want his help to recover. The rejection stung.
articles.abstract: Sandy Weill, the former head of Citigroup, says the bank didn’t want his help to recover. The rejection stung.
articles.lead_paragraph: “THIS is my final annual meeting as chairman,” says Sandy Weill, standing near the window of his office, peering at a grainy photograph of him and his wife on stage at Carnegie Hall more than three years ago. They are smiling broadly, and behind them is a packed house of cheering Citigroup shareholders. A huge banner dangling from the balcony reads “Thank You Sandy.”

articles.headline: U.S. Sees an Opportunity to Press Iran on Nuclear Fuel
articles.snippet: Setbacks in its nuclear program and protests in the streets are making Iran’s leaders vulnerable to strong new sanctions, the Obama administration says.
articles.abstract: Setbacks in its nuclear program and protests in the streets are making Iran’s leaders vulnerable to strong new sanctions, the Obama administration says.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As President Obama faces pressure to back up his year-end ultimatum for diplomatic progress with Iran, the administration says that domestic unrest and signs of unexpected trouble in Tehran’s nuclear program make its leaders particularly vulnerable to strong and immediate new sanctions.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: Yemen’s Chaos Aids the Evolution of a Qaeda Cell
articles.snippet: While the government has been distracted by rebellions, Al Qaeda has built support in Yemen’s poor and lawless territories.
articles.abstract: While the government has been distracted by rebellions, Al Qaeda has built support in Yemen’s poor and lawless territories.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen  Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula has rapidly evolved into an expanding and ambitious regional terrorist network thanks in part to a weakened, impoverished and distracted Yemeni government.

articles.headline: Harvard Teaching Hospitals Cap Outside Pay
articles.snippet: The owner of two hospitals limited outside pay for officials who are on biotechnology or drug companies’ boards.
articles.abstract: The owner of two hospitals limited outside pay for officials who are on biotechnology or drug companies’ boards.
articles.lead_paragraph: The owner of two research hospitals affiliated with the Harvard Medical School has imposed restrictions on outside pay for two dozen senior officials who also sit on the boards of pharmaceutical or biotechnology companies. The limits come in the wake of growing criticism of the ties between industry and academia.

articles.headline: Living on Nothing but Food Stamps
articles.snippet: The number of Americans reporting food stamps as their only income soared 50 percent over the past two years.
articles.abstract: The number of Americans reporting food stamps as their only income soared 50 percent over the past two years.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAPE CORAL, Fla.  After an improbable rise from the Bronx projects to a job selling Gulf Coast homes, Isabel Bermudez lost it all to an epic housing bust  the six-figure income, the house with the pool and the investment property.
articles.byline: By JASON DEPARLE and ROBERT M. GEBELOFF

articles.headline: For Shanghai Fair, Famous Fund-Raiser Delivers
articles.snippet: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton has been raising money for an American pavilion at the 2010 fair.
articles.abstract: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton has been raising money for an American pavilion at the 2010 fair.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In the hectic last week before she became secretary of state, Hillary Rodham Clinton squeezed in a Bon Jovi benefit concert in New York, part of a frantic effort to pay off the debt from her presidential campaign. No sooner had she arrived at the State Department than Mrs. Clinton discovered she needed to start raising money all over again.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and David Barboza

articles.headline: Threats Led to Embassy Closings in Yemen, Officials Say
articles.snippet: The U.S. Embassy cited “ongoing threats by Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula,” the branch responsible for the failed Christmas Day bomb plot.
articles.abstract: The U.S. Embassy cited “ongoing threats by Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula,” the branch responsible for the failed Christmas Day bomb plot.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The United States and Britain decided to close their embassies in the capital of Yemen because of continuing threats from Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, the terrorist group linked to the attempt to bring down an international flight into Detroit on Christmas.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Lax Oversight Caused Crisis, Bernanke Says
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke’s remarks came as he awaited confirmation for a second term as Fed chairman and as he sought greater authority from Congress.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke’s remarks came as he awaited confirmation for a second term as Fed chairman and as he sought greater authority from Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA  Regulatory failure, not low interest rates, was responsible for the housing bubble and subsequent financial crisis of the last decade, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said in a speech on Sunday.

articles.headline: Firms Selling Apps for Simple Phones
articles.snippet: Software companies want to sell functions similar to those found on the iPhone to users of much simpler phones.
articles.abstract: Software companies want to sell functions similar to those found on the iPhone to users of much simpler phones.
articles.lead_paragraph: Given the craze around the iPhone, Motorola Droid, Palm Pre and Nexus One, it might seem that nearly everyone has a smartphone.

articles.headline: Watching TV Together, Miles Apart
articles.snippet: Technology now makes it possible for friends separated by distance to watch TV shows together and then talk about it on Skype.
articles.abstract: Technology now makes it possible for friends separated by distance to watch TV shows together and then talk about it on Skype.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  For the lonely couch potato, help is on the way.

articles.headline: A Savior in the Form of a Tablet
articles.snippet: Is an Apple tablet the second coming of the iPhone: a device that can do anything, including saving embattled print providers from doom?
articles.abstract: Is an Apple tablet the second coming of the iPhone: a device that can do anything, including saving embattled print providers from doom?
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year about this time, I was talking with an executive from Apple about e-readers and print at a conference we were both attending, much of it in the context of the mainstream media’s original sin of giving away content if people happened to be reading it in digital form.

articles.headline: Americans’ Role Seen in Uganda Anti-Gay Push
articles.snippet: Human rights advocates say that three U.S. evangelicals helped set the stage for a bill to execute homosexuals.
articles.abstract: Human rights advocates say that three U.S. evangelicals helped set the stage for a bill to execute homosexuals.
articles.lead_paragraph: KAMPALA, Uganda  Last March, three American evangelical Christians, whose teachings about “curing” homosexuals have been widely discredited in the United States, arrived here in Uganda’s capital to give a series of talks.

articles.headline: News Sites Dabble With a Web Tool for Nudging Local Officials
articles.snippet: On SeeClickFix or on newspaper Web sites, residents can flag problems like potholes to bring them to the attention of government officials.
articles.abstract: On SeeClickFix or on newspaper Web sites, residents can flag problems like potholes to bring them to the attention of government officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: Doug Hardy, an associate editor and Internet supervisor for The Journal Inquirer in Manchester, Conn., wanted to increase page views on its Web site.

articles.headline: Alabama Democrat Toes the G.O.P. Line
articles.snippet: From a deep-red state, Representative Bobby Bright is a Blue Dog, who, for now, enjoys his district’s support.
articles.abstract: From a deep-red state, Representative Bobby Bright is a Blue Dog, who, for now, enjoys his district’s support.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANDALUSIA, Ala.  Among the men who gather every morning at 6 o’clock at the Church’s Chicken here on Three Notch Street, there is general agreement that the Obama administration is doing a very bad job of running the country. And the stakes are as high, as one coffee drinker put it, as the survival of the country’s culture, economy and way of life.

articles.headline: Next Up on Cable TV, Higher Bill for Consumers
articles.snippet: Fox’s deal for new payments from Time Warner Cable will bring higher fees, and it will not be the last time.
articles.abstract: Fox’s deal for new payments from Time Warner Cable will bring higher fees, and it will not be the last time.
articles.lead_paragraph: The performances on “American Idol” may be erratic and the plot twists on “Lost” may be unpredictable, but one facet of television is certain: the costs just keep going up.

articles.headline: 4 Afghan War Veterans Look Back, and Ahead
articles.snippet: Four soldiers, whose lives have been shaped by the war, tell of their experiences and talk about the new strategy.
articles.abstract: Four soldiers, whose lives have been shaped by the war, tell of their experiences and talk about the new strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  One of them, an Army Ranger who served three tours in Afghanistan, led a team into a treacherous mountain ravine to recover the remains of 16 American commandos shot down in a helicopter crash. He still remembers how only their boots had been taken off their bodies by the Taliban.

articles.headline: Trying to Add Portability to Movie Files
articles.snippet: Hollywood and its high-tech partners are trying to create a digital standard that would let consumers buy or rent a movie once and then play it on any device.
articles.abstract: Hollywood and its high-tech partners are trying to create a digital standard that would let consumers buy or rent a movie once and then play it on any device.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is easy to take a DVD to a friend’s house and watch it on his TV. But things are more complicated when digital video downloads are involved. A movie file bought from Blockbuster.com will not work on a Sony HDTV, for example, and videos from iTunes work only on devices with Apple software.

articles.headline: Cold and Signs of Stronger Economy Drive Oil Above $81
articles.snippet: Optimism about a recovery in the United States, the cold weather and a softer dollar helped push the price higher.
articles.abstract: Optimism about a recovery in the United States, the cold weather and a softer dollar helped push the price higher.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  A combination of frigid weather, expectations of an improving economy and new tensions between Russia and Belarus catapulted crude oil prices above $81 a barrel on Monday to the highest close in nearly 15 months.

articles.headline: Divergent Views on Signs of Life in the Economy
articles.snippet: This period might be called the Great Ambiguity — a time of debate over the clarity of economic indicators and the staying power of apparent gains.
articles.abstract: This period might be called the Great Ambiguity — a time of debate over the clarity of economic indicators and the staying power of apparent gains.
articles.lead_paragraph: Signs of revival on the factory floor emerged in the United States and Asia on Monday, fueling exultant buying on Wall Street and reinforcing a sense that genuine economic recovery was unfolding.
